Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling the regulatory network of inositol phosphate signaling in plants

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The inositol phosphates are a class of compound that in plants is thought to play a role in sensing (and making available) energy for the plant to grow and develop. The goal of this project is to understand how inositol phosphates are used to sense the energy status of plant cells, and how they signal this status so that the plant can use this information. The knowledge gained from this project is relevant to plant-derived bioenergy (e.g. biofuels); it will lead not just to an improved understanding but also to strategies to manipulate and maximize bioenergy for desired outcomes such as increased agricultural production of food and biofuels. The project will provide unique, interdisciplinary training in plant science, biochemistry and bioengineering for students and postdoctoral fellows. Outreach activities will focus on engaging high school students in authentic scientific inquiry with a variety of plants generated from this project, using an established program called the Partnership in Research and Education using Plants. Project personnel will also engage elementary students through a 4 day experience called Kids Tech University.

This project will utilize biochemical, genetic and computational modeling approaches to define the inositol pyrophosphate kinase protein interaction network (which includes the sucrose non-fermenting related kinase 1 in plants and the VIP kinases that generate inositol pyrophosphates) in the plant Arabidopsis thaliana and provide knowledge of its role in sensing and signaling a high or low energy status in the plant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phosphate is one of the most important growth-promoting nutrients that can be added to crop plants to speed and enhance growth. The term ?phosphate crisis? has been used to refer to the possibility that the limited world supply will make mining it impossible in the future, and the fact that phosphate run-off from both agricultural and human waste causes harm to the environment (i.e. watersheds and wildlife). The work in this project has delineated the genes and enzymes plants use to make one component of a chemical signaling language used to communicate the phosphate status of the plant. 

Intellectual Merit: In this project we identified the missing enzyme from the plant inositol pyrophosphate synthesis pathway. We also characterized a known enzyme that lacked sufficient detail to understand how it functions. We then used genetics to delete or add extra copies of these genes to plants, in order to show how these genes control synthesis of inositol pyrophosphates, and how this impacts phosphate uptake, and growth and development of plants. 

Broader impacts: Our work has revealed specific genetic targets that can be used in the future to increase phosphate use efficiency in plants, and to reduce our dependence on using large amounts of phosphate in fertilizers. Our science outreach also engaged over 1500 high school students in Virginia. These students have performed their own inquiry-based experiments with our genetic mutants.  This engagement enriches the high school student?s experience with science and reinforcing critical thinking skills.
